an3.128:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.
an3.128:1.2: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Varanasi for alms.
an3.128:1.3: While the Buddha was walking for alms near the cow-hitching place at the wavy leaf fig, he saw a disgruntled monk who was looking for pleasure in external things, unmindful, without situational awareness or immersion, with straying mind and undisciplined faculties.
an3.128:2.2: If you’re bitter, corrupted by putrefaction, flies will, without a doubt, plague and infest you.”
an3.128:2.3: Hearing this advice of the Buddha, that monk was struck with a sense of urgency.
an3.128:2.4: Then, after the meal, on his return from almsround, the Buddha told the mendicants what had happened. …
an3.128:4.4: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha:
an3.128:5.3: and bad, unskillful thoughts are the flies.
an3.128:5.4: If you’re bitter, corrupted by putrefaction, flies will, without a doubt, plague and infest you.
an3.128:6.1: When your eyes and ears are unguarded,
an3.128:6.2: and you’re not restrained in your sense faculties,
an3.128:8.2: if they don’t find serenity in themselves,
an3.128:9.3: they, being peaceful, sleep at ease,
an3.128:9.4: since they’ve got rid of the flies.”
